This comment section is rife with semantic misunderstanding. Tegmark is not positing that symbolic mathematics (or whatever moniker you want to give it), as in the language itself, is somehow the physical basis of the universe (and pointing out that a language is not an elementary substance is a silly counter argument). And mathematics being a pragmatic shorthand (as all languages essentially are) does not somehow diminish the elementary truth it describes or somehow make what it describes anthropogenic. He’s saying that which is described and measured by what we call mathematics - logic, information, objectivity, if-then, however you want to descriptively pen it in - is the initial condition that provides for the infinitely complex logical/mathematical structure that we perceive. Indeed, a sufficiently complex mathematical structure (structure being a flawed term since it linguistically imbues the universe with physicality and dilutes the point that physicality is macroscopic perception), one that could be governed by quantum strictures and physical laws in much the same way that a triangle is governed by tenets like sine/co-sine etc, could be perceived by self-aware substructures as “physical”. He’s not saying that existence is akin to Neo’s world-view at the end of the Matrix with scrolling numbers (or symbols/language of any kind) - the universe is far too complex for something so banal. He’s saying that the only way a mathematical structure so inconceivably vast and complex could be perceived by its constituent sub-structures would be via emergent properties described in their base form by that mathematical/logical substrate (color, spatial relationships, time, the list goes on). That substrate is what we define and measure with mathematical symbols/theorems, etc.

I understand the point being made here, and on most parts I agree, but I think saying that everything around us is “made up” of math is like saying that everything we talk about is “made up” of words. I don’t disagree that everything we know can be described using math, but think of it this way: if I come along and say an apple is red, round, shiny, and delicious (which is a fact, not an opinion), then I have just described that apple using words. That doesn’t mean the apple is “made up” of my words, though, as someone could just as easily say the apple is lightweight, watery, and hard to cut, and claim that those are the most important characteristics of that apple. I think everything we see around us— stars, planets, sheep— can be described using math very well, but that mathematical description isn’t the end-all be-all of what that object truly IS. I think knowing a sheep’s cuteness is just as important as knowing the atoms that make it up, because while atoms and quarks provide an in-depth understanding of how the sheep fits into the bigger picture of our reality, they also don’t tell you what you’re seeing with your eyes, and having words that describe the ways the universe interacts with our bodies are just as important as having words for why.

In sum, I believe that the universe is no more “made up” of math than it is any other language, because no singular “way” to describe an object is the most complete or correct one,

(I also have other opinions about how assuming the universe is inherently mathematical implies the universe was created for some purpose or was made to be described in a certain way, and believing this concept only proves mankind’s everlasting need to find patterns where they really aren’t there, but I can save that for a YouTube video with less than 3.7k comments on it.)

I quite enjoy the videos on this channel, but it always bothers how Physics is blindly overglorified and portrayed as the perfect explanation to everything.

I mean, he stresses the "beauty" of a Physics formula simply "because it works". He deconstructs complex concepts in Physics because naturally, some are difficult to visualize in our perception of reality. This video is posted as a sort of implicit slap against beliefs outside of science, and yet, there is a type of hypocrisy in doing so while believing in science just as blindly or implying that science is always correct.

For example, you can argue against quantum physics, relativity, and everything with the same argument used here against religion: "if I can't see it, it doesn't exist." In the same way, where Physics explains a change in energy during nuclear beta decay as an antineutrino, religion can explain it as an act of God. People solely arguing in favor of religion could claim that Physics simply makes up arbitrary concepts, particles, constants, forces, laws, and other observations as it goes, without an absolute, consistent process or explanation for doing so. People arguing solely in favor of Physics will claim that religion is merely a collection of stories that is easily disproven today by our observations of the natural world. That age-old question: who is right?

Unless you're a hardcore Solipsist, it's pretty safe to say that the universe will continue to exist regardless of what explanation we give for its origin and if we all agree on that explanation. I'm not personally arguing for either, because I think there are better things to argue. However, it is worth it to point out biases or fallacies in how we justify our explanations.

This minutephysics video suffered from a bit of Confirmation Bias in the argument that just because what we seem to find is explained by Physics that EVERYTHING we could possibly find could be explained by Physics. Much like when education was dominated by religious beliefs, we believe that what we currently know is true regardless of our history of constantly being incorrect about our explanations of the world around us.

People who believe blindly one way or another will continue to bicker over the debate of religion versus science without addressing the real issue of how we justify or validate what we "know". With both, there are valid ways to prove and disprove them, and the ones that we find most reasonable or appealing, we choose. The problem occurs when people think we have to choose to believe one or another, especially when they are not even educated on either one. At that point, both sides are trusting in religion or science to dictate their beliefs. Instead of exploring those explanations for themselves, people are taking others' mere words for absolute truth.

This is one of the primary arguments against religion, but it occurs extremely often with science as well. In general, there is always danger believing in absolute truth, because we often forget that just because something is proven by our scientific method, it's true. We've been wrong many many times, precisely because there is no secret "answer sheet" to the meaning of the universe, and just because a claim is preceded by "in a recent scientific study, scientists have found..." doesn't mean it's true, or that it can't be disproven.

Contrary to what minutephysics implies, there's no absolute assurance that any formula that we can come up with will always work (Newtonian mechanics, gravity at a small enough level) even within the realm of what we can prove. Similarly, our beliefs in religion don't outright equate to truth within the frame our lifetimes.

My problem with this video is the favoritism and lack of objectivity. I very much enjoy learning from this channel without the underlying agenda of having to pick science other any beliefs I may have. If this channel was meant to be purely informative, this predicament shouldn't be something to be addressed by this video or implied by other videos. I realize that not everyone will agree with me, but I just wanted to point out what I found were some flaws with this video, and why it doesn't make sense to be included with the rest.

I'd argue that consciousness is not mathematical. Thought (neural interaction) is mathematical, but experiencing thought (being conscious) is not. Abstract concepts are a fundamentally different class of data to anything numeric. There's no way to make a number equal red. You can use numbers to identify it by its wavelength and even the specific associated neurons it fires, but the actual perceived concept of what red is is something else entirely. If there's any evidence of a divine element in the universe, it's the existence of a part of us that is actually capable of experiencing the quality of these abstract concepts. This is why I believe belief in a soul is not without reason.

To preempt some counterarguments: "Consciousness is an illusion." That calls into question the validity of what is perceived, not the perceiver. Something still has to perceive an illusion.

And to clarify: I claim that only perception is not mathematical. Two identical thinking systems, one with conscious experience and one without, could very well behave the exact same way. This means there's no way to validate consciousness' existence outside your own perception, and though it'd be more consistent for everyone to be the same, it technically leaves open the possibility of everyone else being "philosophical zombies" (look it up).

I do not concern myself over other peoples' beliefs, and none of you should either. You cannot easily change someone's faith, because faith by its definition is an irrational choice that people make with evidence that's basically "good enough" for them. Those people may think that they "feel something", or believe that is has helped them throughout life in some way or another. Whether or not this sensation can be quantified and explained realistically (with our current technology let's say), is irrelevant to people who choose to have this kind of faith. So arguing against faith is a completely pointless and fruitless thing to do. Furthermore, it will certainly cause 99.99% of "believers" to go on the defensive. So don't poke the bear. Any bear. Not just a religious one. :)

Psychologically, the other critically important thing is - the degree to which humans are able to be convinced of something that has no tangible matter, is fantastic. That is to say, they can be convinced of something for 100.00% certainty, and in many cases will defend those beliefs with their lives. This is actually just another area of human psychology, and it's not limited to religion. It applies to many situations. People in North Korea have the same degree of "undying faith" in their ideas of reality as many religious extremists, for instance. There are many much milder examples too in everyday life. All humans are flawed. Welcome to humans 101.

Before you try to argue against religion guys, try to consider the following:
-Things that are obvious to you may certainly not be obvious to others. Your arguments carry a lot of assumptions with them, which are in fact not shared with the people you're trying to convince.
-People who believe in something strongly, aren't looking to be proven wrong. Think about it. But they ARE looking to shut down any perceived hatred directed at that which they believe (wouldn't you, purely instinctively?). There is no outcome, in which the other people will just say "Oh ok, I see everything clearly now." Sounds stupid right? Because it is. It's not that simple.
-People who believe in something strongly, may have a totally different conception of the world. The things which you "assume" to be completely true, such as the earth being around, and the air being breathable can be directly compared to let's say religious tenets which those people have accepted with an equal degree of belief, and on which their entire worldview is built. Get it? You're not going to have any luck arguing because of that degree of conviction that underlies their entire mentality. Think about it, is it easy to say 1 sentence to some random person, and change their entire conception of life and existence? Of course it's not. Such mental changes take YEARS, not the few minutes that people spend reading long youtube comments such as this one.

Anti-religious sentiments will get you nowhere with very religious people. In most cases, you have neither the brainpower nor the detailed knowledge of those (or any) religions, which is required at minimum to argue effectively. Don't waste your time and do something more productive. You'll be much happier as a result.

As a final point - don't we all have something that may be important to us, but is in fact completely unimportant to other people? Would you like to have the right to choose which aspects of life are important to you? Or would you like to be forced to only accept some "standard issue" government-enforced sets of beliefs? Freedom of religion falls into this category. Yes, there are times when religious extremism causes big problems for others, but that is simply the kind of human insanity we've always had on this planet. World War 2 didn't happen so long ago, and it wiped out 60+ million people. War may be war, but each of us is born alone, dies alone, and is personally responsible for all actions that we undertake. "But the general told me to do it" isn't good enough. You cannot justify that with basic logic without making and accepting a huge number of assumptions - just like with religion. Wiping out religion will not wipe out crazy people. In fact, in many cases, religion keeps crazy people from acting on their craziness. In this world, it's always from the frying pan and into the fire - get used to it and focus on constructive things. :) Positivity breeds positivity, and the opposite is true as well.

We naturally arrived at this model because multiple things could exist at the same time (e.g. there are 2 sheep), but at the time the universe didn't "care" that there were 2 sheep. In the same way statistics came about - and so happened to be a good way to describe quantum mechanics.

Ultimately our failure to unite relatively ("algebra") and quantum mechanics ("statistics") demonstrates that the universe is not mathematical (as we have defined it): the universe likely does have a language but it is not a form of mathematics that we understand yet.

In addition the voice-over used English to describe the universe, "a sheep", "electrons", etc. English (or any spoken language) can describe the universe in ways that mathematics cannot. We can verbally conceptualize the universe with eachother but these concepts are hard (or impossible) to describe in mathematics. English is as-good a descriptor of the universe as mathematics is. It cannot quantify or predict accurate outcomes - as that is the realm of math, however math cannot poetically depict a beautiful waterfall (which is as much a part of the universe as the Higgs Field is). Newton's Theory of Gravity came from "the apple falls from the tree" after all.

It doesn't mean that the universe is intrinsically mathematical - it just means that one of our models happens to fit the universe's two differing behaviours better than our other models; it does not mean we have the perfect model (or language).

I don't think this is entirely coherent.  For one thing, there's no evidence that numbers are real beyond that we have defined them to be real.  There aren't any "2s" anywhere in the universe.  Secondly, it completely ignores the possibility that the whole may be greater than the sum of its parts: eggs, flour, icing, milk, salt, sugar, etc. are components of a cake, but none of the parts can become cake without the interaction of all of them.  Thirdly, this ignores completely the possibility of alien logic.  Aristotle once said that if a man disagreed on certain axioms (ie. a=a) that any conversation with him would be impossible, because for all intents and purppses, you'd be speaking a foreign language to him.  It's entirely possible that math may only appear to be uniquely efficacious in describing nature because we have no experience defining nature without math.  Were we to contact another civilization that has also obtained a high degree of scientific achievement, it is entirely concievable that they would have do so without math; simply because we can't imagine how it would happen, does not mean that it cannot, nor does it mean that the universe is mathematical because our logic cannot concieve of it being another way. Mathematics is the result of the universe and is able to describe it due to its inherent continuity.  Yet any values placed upon it are arbitrary and hold value only because the universe is used to calibrate those values.  Thus, saying the universe is mathematical is like saying that dollars are used to count gold.  In the end, the relative nature between universal aspects are important, and absolute mathematics only stems because certain values are taken as constant even though there are no constants that we know of.  (only when one thing is made constant can we relate others to it, but if another aspect is taken as constant, then the original would become dynamic). - Light is a great example of this, if light were to be made a constant velocity, then space and time would shift around it according to a mathematical relationship, however when a specific timeframe is made to be constant, then other timeframes and perspectives on the speed of light become dynamic.  Mathematics do not govern the the universe, yet relationships follow mathematical patterns within statistical error.  This is the emergence of averages from the chaos.  Order from chaos much like the Sierpinski triangle, is what allows us to mathematically categorize this order into mathematics.  But the only mathematical attributes that can be placed on the chaos is a probability distribution.  Yes mathematics applies only as far as we can relate physical properties to one another, yet one property standing on its own has no mathematical properties because it requires a relationship to be mathematically formulated.  Only the fact that the universe holds mathematical continuity is what allows us the formulate it with respect to itself.

This question seems sort of meaningless to me, not in the sense that it doesn't make sense so much as it feels like it is missing the point. If this question were asked by a Buddhist monk, his teacher would be telling him to unask the question.

Take a video game, for example. Let's say Super Mario Brothers. It is a complex series of computer instructions designed to present the player with an engaging interactive experience. It is very mathematical in nature from the coder's perspective. But from the player's, and, if you think about it, even the designer's perspective, it really isn't that mathematical at all. It's a "story" (massive scare quotes) about a plumber running through a magical wonderland, gaining power by eating mushrooms and picking flowers, all to save a kidnapped princess from an evil, dragon-turtle king. Try to model THAT mathematically.

While yes, on a fundamental level, almost(?) everything can be represented by an equation, that's not how we see it. Even if we're incredible, revolutionary scientists, that's not how we function in everyday life. An apple is an apple before it is a complex mathematic model made up of molecules aligned in a specific way with specific coordinates and made up of muons and bosons and gluons and schmuons, all of which have only mathematical properties. It's a freaking apple.

And besides, the mathematical models we can use to represent the apple are just that: models, informational representations of real things. The real world isn't made up of information. Some might even argue that it doesn't even inherently contain information, and that all information is is the notions, ideas, and descriptions that humans write down about the world.

Is the world just made up of a bunch mathematically modelable particles flying around and bumping into each other? You could say that. But you could just as easily say that it's made up of people, places, and things. And while I love math and science, and while I think it's great that we can do all these crazy calculations, it seems a lot more comforting to me to think of the things around me as units themselves. They may not be indivisible -- an apple can be cut in half -- but they are still more than the summation of its parts.

One could conclude that the universe is just a complex calculator, however that view has a *flaw - its only valid within our perceivable scale.

Lets look at it from the other direction, say the basic concepts of cause and effect were not consistent, you would have things happen without any cause and events could happen without any effects.  It would be chaos and without predictability.

If it were to be like that on our scale, 2 oranges would be a grape or maybe pudding, very confusing. Math wouldn't work at all.

Unfortunately (the *flaw), randomness is what exists beyond what we are able to observe (quantum mechanics); meaning the underlining calculations are non-existent/ however on our scale we see the average of what happens, so while we see an orange, beyond our perception things are coming and going without cause or effect.

So the better question would be, if there are no underlining cause-effect rules operating - then what is causing math/order to exist.

This is why a scientist can believe in God - as the reason why we exist in an orderly state when the underlining mechanics are non existent.

Oh, and saying math is the average from random does not explain how the average is maintained when the randomness is the source.

In his book, Max Tegmark explains that his Mathematical Universe Hypothesis (MUH) relies on a Theory of Everything (ToE) which is isomorphic to the External Physical Reality (EPR). This argument is also circular because isomorphism can only be applied to two mathematical objects (here, the ToE and EPR). He sets out to prove that the universe is a mathematical object by first assuming the universe is a mathematical object!

If sheep and people are composed of elements that reduce to elementary particles, does that mean that an adequate description of sheep or people can be given in terms of microphysical properties and relations which are mathematical?  For example, thoughts, language acquisition and use, creativity/innovation, beliefs and emotions-- cannot be understood in terms of subatomic particles at this time (if ever). The idea that psychological and social descriptions can be eliminated and replaced with concepts used at the level of microphysics depends on the assumption that these qualitative properties can be explained in the same way that smaller and more basic phenomena are explained. This is a promisory note. Nobody can say much of interest about persons or sentient animals generally by means of mathematical physics. Questions about complexity and perhaps emergence need, I think, to at least be addressed.We don't really have a good understanding of  consciousness (which is where qualitative properties like "fluffiness" or "love" arise). I'd lump myself in with the ones who say "math" is a word to describe a system defined by a set of definitions and rules, made up by humans. More specifically, a system to define and work with QUANTITY. Now, everything we experience is by definition shaped by how the human mind works, so that shouldn't be a problem. But math alone is not enough to describe all we experience (and hence, the universe). We need more than "how much", we also need "what".

If I describe something white, math can tell me how white it is, by putting a number on the wavelength and intensity of light it irradiates, and how my eye perceives and registers that in my brain. But what is "wavelength, light, brain, eye", etc.? For that to have meaning, I need to know what all those concepts are first. And we do not form definitions for that from a mathematical background, but from experiences stored in our memories. The math comes later, as a useful tool to interconnect those things.

And since I define reality as everything we experience, which means not only the quantities but also the concepts, math does not "make up the entire universe." Words do, too. Without words, math could not describe reality (and arguably without the concepts of quantity described by math, words could not describe reality as accurately). Hence the universe does not consist of only math.

Math is just a method of putting into an understandable format what we observe in the universe. In that way to say that the Universe is Math is somewhat like saying that Red is a Color. However, our mathematics is not always sound and because we are not all knowing it may be that we will need to change our math to fit different situations in order to properly continue describing what we observe. What I find worrying is when scientists attempt instead to change the universe by introducing invisible undetectable things to try to make their math work. (I'm looking at you Dark Matter/Energy) When instead they should ask the fundamental question of rather or not their current model actually works or if a different approach may be more sound. (Electromagnetism > Gravity for example.)

I always have a problem when people try to say how amazing it is that the whole universe is mathematical. There seems to be a crucial missing piece in this amazement that nobody can get across to average people: why is there a limit on math?

If I can make a parallel with language - I see something I've never seen or heard of before and I name it. Then I learn about what it does and is and find a way to describe it so others who see this same thing will know that it is this thing that I named. The language didn't exist before I made it up but language is flexible and I added something to it.

 Math seems to be the same. We encounter some process and describe it mathematically, if it's beyond our current methods we invent new ones. If there is no definite solution possible we can make an approximation so accurate that the error is unmeasurable and we call it solved. If approximations don't count as a mathematical description then the three body problem and the wave function of every atom other than hydrogen are all already non-mathematical. We also have things like the spin vector of a particle that can only be described by probablilities, where no equation can predict a single measurement with 100% certainty. Yet we stretch the definition of "mathematical" to include these approximate and probabilistic descriptions. Why can't we stretch our definitions and our methods to everything we could ever possibly encounter?

So what am I missing? Is Max Tegmark afraid that someday there will be something that is utterly baffling to the human mind? Or is there some fundamental property of mathematics that allows there to be a limit? I am genuinely curious.

"Is the Universe entirely explainable by mathematics" or something among these lines would've been a little more accurate a title, IMO.

The foundations of mathematical descriptions of nature begins with basic process of language: associating symbols to experience.  Once you can explain that process, you get the rest: numbers are symbols counting recognition, metrics apply numbers to processes with span, etc. but these are all just extension of recognizing into symbols.  Philosophy has discussed this for years - it's the basis of Phenomenology and was much of the point of Wittgenstein's investigations.  Quine's "Word and Object" is a seminal study.

And as has been known for quite some time, all that is needed for us to build pattern recognition in the world is that information sources may be correlated.  Correlation in the world allows us to build patterns, it allows description in symbols, it allows the transfer of information, and it allows description of change which can be expressed mathematically.  So the question of the appropriateness of mathematical description is really the question of why there are correlations in the information of the universe.

It's a shame none of that is in this video, as that has been pretty standard philosophical discourse for the past 100 years.  It also helps describe something related that is left mysterious in the video: anything that is experienced has established correlation with mental processes, so anything in the world that fails to have correlations in the world fails to be experienced.

That's really the fundamental flaw in most every "fluff" paper I've read by Tegmark. He basically does the same thing that a lot of arm-chair philosophers do; he presents an idea in colloquial language, using some words that are very loaded (eg, mathematical, information, integrated, structure) to appeal to our common sense, without rigorously defining his terms, and then makes (in my opinion the flaw in his argument) a really big jump to some math that the layperson can't understand, as if that could replace a proper semantic definition. Classic proof by intimidation. It's like if the Principia gave an intuitive treatise on "motion" and then immediately jumped to the Lagrangian formalism with no derivation and no statement of Newton's Laws as if that proved something.
I read a critique of his recent paper on consciousness, which pointed out that if you reread the paper, but replaced the terms "information" and "integrated" etc, which we all understand pretty intuitively, with meaningless strings of characters, it's pretty much impossible to see where the math arises from. Basically, he needs to state "Tegmark's laws" in a concise, exact form, without ambiguity, before these papers will be anything more than fluff.

Certainly there is a lot of math in the universe, but there is also QUALIA. Sheep "cuteness", or in other words: subjective feelings (i'm not talking about the biochemistry processes behind them), the quality of visual information, the quality of sounds, of touches, the quality of flavors... Those are unshareable informations, because they will always be part of our internal "selves".

For instance, you can NEVER explain to a born blind person what the color RED really is. You can make aproximations, you can make associations, but that knowlegdement is unaccessible to him forever, because he lacks the instrumentation to interpret it for himself. Hence, since math is a language to universally describe and transmit information in a very precise manner, and there are no math to transmit nor interpret qualia, hence we reached a blind spot. Or at least, a point of incompleteness (just like on Godel's theorem)...

In fact, i think for myself that math is at least entangled with qualia (if it is not just a byproduct of it), since we can only describe what we observe. And even when math can be used to describe something that is not definite (examples in quantum mechanics), that description will be meaningless without the true definition and observation, because the objective reality only manifests itself when it can be measured... statistics outside the math world means nothing.

And since both math and qualia cannot be ignored when describing our reality, because we already know that both exists (by our own individual experiences), we must deal with the fact that math will never be able to explain everything, hence it cannot BE everything, nor we will be able to know about everything (again, just like on Godel's theorem).

So, even if i appreciate very much the authors efforts to bring up this kind of description for our universe, i am still seeing it as only a partial explanation for the questions, unless of course someone points me to a specific mathematical explanation that is able to address the issues i posted above, so any other insight (if any exists) will be appreciated. But if it does not exist, then i think we reached a point that we won't be able to overcome and accept it as a natural limitation that is intrinsic to our very nature.

Perhaps the universe is purely mathematical, perhaps there is a divinity behind it, perhaps everything is destined. These questions can't be answered fully, so why not take all the sides and make a story that works for you? I believe in an ultimate divine, but also that the universe is VERY mathematical. Some call me a heathen, some call me a religious fool, but the end goal is to find a belief system that works with YOU. That is the beauty of human belief, that we can all have these different views on the world around us, and none of us are right or wrong, we are simply different in the way we choose to perceive things around us. Right and wrong don't exist, as reality is completely subjective to the experiences of the person. The sooner we learn to put aside, "my god is right, your god is wrong, science is right, spirituality is right, etc." the sooner we can live in peace with one another, embracing each others views.

As a Mathematics student, though I'm willing to be proven wrong, I would say this is categorically a flawed view of the universe, and here's why.

Some parts of reality, as I understand it, are entirely modelled by statistics at the moment.

Statistics, in the mathematical sense, has no mathematical link to statistics in the real world sense. Statistics works with arbitrary things that apparently model the real world, and do so fairly well, but these things aren't derived from reality. Rather, they are a number of interesting numerical properties of functions defined from real numbers to [0,1] which follow certain laws (which I will not go into in detail here).

Importantly, there fundamentally is no way to tell whether the statistics actually maps to reality or not. You can't even say "it is likely so" because you are appealing to statistics- again a set of mathematics which may or may not have a real bearing on the world. As such, you need more than mathematics to model the real actual universe. You need to make an assumption that a link is there. This is not a mathematical way of thinking, and therefore cannot be mathematical. In order for the universe to actually be entirely a mathematical one would have to establish a mathematical proof which linked mathematics and reality, which whilst not necessarily impossible, has evaded mathematicians for the the entire history of our subject, and I do not believe it is possible to do so. 

Whether there is a philosophical link between mathematics and reality is a different question, but in order to allow such a link one must allow a notion of proof or truth without mathematics.

I fully believe such questions should be approached from a philosophic lens, with a  nod to mathematics.

Mathematics will tell you under what circumstances 1+1=2, and under what circumstances 1+1=0, but it can't give you a link between all those interesting facts and reality, and further, that isn't the role of mathematics. The nature of the universe should be based on a ground-up philosophical set of axioms, and those should be constantly examined and scrutinised, and then perhaps we shall have our answer about the nature of the universe.

I have trouble believing that math can exist outside of our perceptions, as every definition of basic mathematical concepts I've ever seen has been circular.  I prefer to think of math as a tool of human invention, without any kind of existence outside our own minds.

The only "part" of the universe that doesn't appear mathematical to me (based on my limited information as a lowly undergrad), is the randomness of quantum mechanics.  While math gives us many ways to describe random phenomena (probability, statistics, etc.), it is by definition impossible to create truly random numbers.  If there existed a method to create a random number, then it is possible to use that method to predict what the number is, making it not random.

Therefore, either the universe is capable of things that mathematics is not, or quantum mechanics isn't truly as random as many physicists predict.
